results.title: Braveheart [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, ICON, Ladd Company, Mel Gibson, Alan Ladd Jnr and Bruce Davey
results.brief_description: Medieval epic set in 13th Century Scotland. “Braveheart” follows the fortunes of the legendary Sir William Wallace, the Scottish Higlander who led his people in rebellion against Edward Ist. of England. Gibson’s film made its mark on the 1995 Academy Awards, being an epic in the old style, filled with gigantic battle scenes and larger than life characters. Starring Mel Gibson as William Wallace, Sophie Marceau and Patrick McGoohan. A tale about oppression and the courage to oppose it.

results.title: Brassed off
results.creator_credit: Channel Four Films, Miramax Films, Steve Abbot and Mark Herman
results.brief_description: The Grimethorpe Colliery Band doesn’t have much to play for these days with the shadow of the mine’s imminent closure looming over them. Danny (Pete Postlethwaite) doesn’t share this view, as band master he sees the band as the life blood of the community. His son has the opposite view, blaming the conservative Thatcher government for the community’s misfortune. The band receives a lift in spirits with the arrival of Gloria (Tara Fitzgerald), a fluglehorn player eager to join the band but unbeknown to them is also part of the “management” team making decisions about the mine. For Andy (Ewan McGregor), Gloria’s appearance sparks memories of their brief teenage romance. When the mine closes and Danny is placed into hospital, plans for competing in the National Championship are placed on hold. After a series of conflicts however the band discovers a way of venting their anger and telling their story as well as that of miners elsewhere. An enjoyable comedy with a serious message about economic policy and the mining community. Also starring Jim Carter, Phillip Jackson, Stephen Moore, Ken Colley and Peter Gunn.

results.title: Branded to kill [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Nikkatsu Kabushiki Kaisha, Kaneo Iwai and Seijun Suzuki
results.brief_description: Hanado Goro, no. 3 gunman in the Tokyo underworld after killing no. 2 and bungling the fourth of a series of imaginatively executed ‘hits’, finds himself playing cat-and-mouse with the dangerous no. 1. Explosions of violence are punctuated by moments of unexpected lyricism and intermingled with bizarre humour (Hanado is sexually aroused by the smell of boiled rice). After making dozens of run-of-the-mill genre films for Nikkatsu, Sejun Suzuki began transforming the banal material assigned to him into farcically hyperbolic absurdist thrillers reinventing the yakuza film by drawing on Japanese comical literary, theatrical and cinematic traditions (see also “Tokyo drifter”), in the process attracting both a cult following and the ire of Nikkatsu. Cast includes Jo Shishido, Koji Nanbara, Isao Tamagawa, Annu Mari, Mariko Ogawa and Hiroshi Minami. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Boyz'n the hood
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Steve Nicolaides and John Singleton
results.brief_description: In the 1980s, spurned on by the success of Spike Lee, young Afro-American directors began to develop scripts and films for the mainstream American movie industry. Previously, black filmmakers in the United States had to work completely outside the system or in the exploitation genres if they wished to work with black actors and black themes. John Singleton’s “Boyz ‘n the Hood” was one of the pioneering works of this new Hollywood cinema. Cuba Gooding Jr. plays a young man who has grown up in the severely economically deprived inner-city ghetto of South Central Los Angeles. He has to decide whether to follow his friends into a life of gang criminality and drug use or whether to leave behind the “hood” and pursue an academic career as his embittered former activist father wants him to (Larry Fishburne). Refusing the exploitative excesses that dehumanise African-American ghetto characters in most action films, “Boyz n’ the Hood” reveals the complexity of growing up in a segregated world in which entrenched unemployment has meant that for young men, only the drug economy provides any chance for success or wealth. Cast also includes Ice Cube.

results.title: Boys Town
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Loews Inc, John W. Considine and Norman Taurog
results.brief_description: The moving story of Father Flanagan (Spencer Tracy) who battled the courts, the community but mostly the odds to build Boys Town in Nebraska, a home for abandoned, homeless boys, regardless of race, creed or colour. When the tough, rebellious Whitey March (Mickey Rooney) arrives, Father Flanagan faces the challenge of his life. He must fight not only to save the self-destructive youth, but to save Boys Town itself. Spencer Tracy won his second Academy Award for his performance and Mickey Rooney excels as Whitey, proving his strength as a talented dramatic actor. Eleanore Griffin and Dore Schary also earned Oscars for their original story. Co-starring Henry Hull, Leslie Fenton and Gene Reynolds. “Boys Town” will steal your heart and leave you with something even better - inspiration.

results.title: Boys on the side
results.creator_credit: Studio Canal+, Regency Enterprises, Alcor Films, New Regency Pictures, Heva Productions, Monarchy Enterprises B. V., Arnon Mitchell, Steven Reuther, Herbert Ross and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: Three women share a car going West and laughs, tears and togetherness unfold along the way. They each have secrets to reveal, strengths to impart and vital moments of self discovery; and their shared friendship subsequently becomes family. Whoopi Goldberg (a wisecracking, lesbian club singer), Mary Louise Parker (a finicky HIV+ real-estate agent) and Drew Barrymore (a free spirit) join forces in this celebration of camaraderie, the art of survival, the gift of laughter and the miracle of friendship and caring by Herbert Ross, the director of The Turning Point and Steel Magnolias. Co-starring Matthew McConaughey, James Remar, Billy Wirth, Anita Gillette, Dennis Boutsikaris, Amy Acquino, Stan Egi and Estelle Parsons.

results.title: Boxcar Bertha
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP), Roger Corman and Martin Scorsese
results.brief_description: Set in the Depression era of the late 1920s, Scorsese’s first studio feature film is a spirited and deftly executed gangster drama. Barbara Hershey plays Bertha, a young woman who on becoming homeless during the Depression, joins an itinerant group of unemployed travellers. Jumping from train to train, she makes box-cars her home and is introduced to socialist politics by her lover, Big Bill Shelley (David Carradine). When the police and state, acting with a deliberate cruelty, attempt to break apart the delicate communities built by the unemployed Bertha and Big Bill become train robbers: on an ironic take of the Robin Hood legend, they steal from the rich and they give it to the Trade Unions. Working within the strict budgetary confines of Roger Corman’s B-grade exploitation genre, Scorsese illuminates a fairly conventional gangster narrative with a glowing romanticism. In some of the more violent sequences, and in particular the highly charged climax, the film introduces themes that are to be continuing concerns for Scorsese over the length of his controversial career. Based on the memoirs of Boxcar Bertha herself.

results.title: Bowling for Columbine [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Dog Eat Dog Films, Salter Street Films, VIF 2, Jim Czarnecki, Kathleen Glynn and Michael Moore
results.brief_description: Michael Moore’s 2002 documentary came in the wake of the burgeoning fame and infamy that the social and media commentator, agent provocateur, satirist and political activist garnered with his television series, “The Awful truth” and publications including “Stupid white men”. In this work Moore addresses the problem of violence in America, focusing on gun culture, the prevalence of gun ownership and the sanctity of the American right to bear arms. Moore’s approach is to interview a variety of people attempting to depict a tapestry that may explain America’s relationship to guns. Among his interviewees are student survivors of the 1999 Columbine school massacre, National Rifle Association spokesperson and actor, Charlton Heston, politicians, police and various gun enthusiasts. Moore tries to dispel myths that are propagated as an explanation as to why American society is so at war with itself - its bloody history, the volume of guns amid the population, violence in the media, American’s preponderance for violent video games and films. Moore questions these theories by focusing on other less violent countries with these same qualities. One of Moore’s strongest theories is that the scare-mongering prevalent in society, broadcast through the media, and the popularity of reality TV shows, such as “COPS”, promotes the notion that danger is omnipresent to the individual and must be countered. Winner of Best Documentary at the 2003 Academy Awards, Moore’s acceptance speech earned him even greater notoriety when he criticised US President Bush and the war on Iraq.

results.title: Bottle rocket
results.creator_credit: Colombia Pictures, Gracie Films, Polly Platt, Cynthia Hargrave and Wes Anderson
results.brief_description: Wes Anderson’s first feature film is a whimsical tale of three suburban misfits who attempt to commit the perfect robbery but end up in trouble with the local “Godfather” (played by James Caan). The conventions of the crime film are used as launch-pads for Anderson to construct a low-key but nevertheless deeply affecting romance about small-time lives and experience. The script, co-written by Anderson and star Owen Wilson, takes three friends on a mid-Western road trip in which Anthony (Luke Wilson) finds love with a Mexican immigrant, Inez (Lumi Cavazos); Dignan (Owen Wilson) plays out all his fantasies of being a master criminal; and Bob Mapplethorpe (Robert Musgrave) finds out that blood is, indeed, thicker than water. By finding beauty and comedy in the deeply suburban locales, Anderson is able to satirize the insularity of bourgeois American families and values without being condescending or cynical. The idiosyncratic, colourful and playful mise-en-scene of “Rushmore” and “The Royal Tenenbaums” is clearly evident in Anderson’s debut.

By finding beauty and comedy in the deeply suburban locales, Anderson is able to satirize the insularity of bourgeois American families and values without being condescending or cynical. The idiosyncratic, colourful and playful mise-en-scene of “Rushmore” and “The Royal Tenenbaums” is clearly evident in Anderson’s debut.
description_for_label: Wes Anderson’s first feature film is a whimsical tale of three suburban misfits who attempt to commit the perfect robbery but end up in trouble with the local “Godfather” (played by James Caan). The conventions of the crime film are used as launch-pads for Anderson to construct a low-key but nevertheless deeply affecting romance about small-time lives and experience. The script, co-written by Anderson and star Owen Wilson, takes three friends on a mid-Western road trip in which Anthony (Luke Wilson) finds love with a Mexican immigrant, Inez (Lumi Cavazos); Dignan (Owen Wilson) plays out all his fantasies of being a master criminal; and Bob Mapplethorpe (Robert Musgrave) finds out that blood is, indeed, thicker than water. By finding beauty and comedy in the deeply suburban locales, Anderson is able to satirize the insularity of bourgeois American families and values without being condescending or cynical. The idiosyncratic, colourful and playful mise-en-scene of “Rushmore” and “The Royal Tenenbaums” is clearly evident in Anderson’s debut.
